Bott = Planck = sheared Rees, part iv

Aug 6, 2020

We will pick up straight from last time.

Part iv: applications

Our goal in this post is to understand deformation quantization in characteristic following Bezrukavnikov-Kaledin through the perspective that deformation quantizations in characteristic are refined by -actions (and they are “the same” in characteristic zero, as expressed by the equation ). I’m not going to try to prove their main results from a homotopical perspective in this post, but I’ll try to explain how the structures they’re interested in naturally fall out of homotopy theory. Also, in previous posts, I was using cohomological grading (which I’m very uncomfortable with), so we will switch to homological grading in this post. We will also only work with odd primes (but this is mostly cosmetic).

Let us begin by recalling some definitions from their paper. Fix a field of characteristic , and let be a commutative -algebra. A Frobenius-constant quantization of is a flat associative -algebra such that (this is just a quantization) along with a multiplicative central -linear splitting map which kills , and . This gives a Frobenius-linear operation sending

A quantized algebra along with the datum of a Frobenius-linear operation that satisfies some axiomatic properties that satisfies is said to be a restricted quantized algebra. Using the above formula to define given , we see that restricted quantized algebras are the same thing as a Frobenius-constant quantization.

I would like to explain a homotopical interpretation of Frobenius-constant quantizations, from our point of view that : we will see that Frobenius-constant quantizations have a natural homotopical analogue, given by cyclotomic spectra. The above expression for tells us that

According to our equation , we should think of as sending to — but the only way this can be a homogeneous expression is if lives in degree . However, the map would then not be homogeneous. No worries; we can just scale by instead, giving a map by

but there are signs in front of the terms. Here, is the th lower-indexed Dyer-Lashof operation. Observe that because increases the degree, and is coconnective, we have that for once

where I believe I’ve got the signs right in this equation.

Suppose instead that is not , but only . What is the appropriate fix then? In that case, the expression still holds — but the map is not additive. Rather, we have

where is the Lie polynomial specified by the generating function

Here, the adjoint action is given by the Browder bracket (which shifts degrees by ). It’s tricky to find a reference for this statement, so let me point out that it’s Theorem III.1.3(5) in Cohen-Lada-May.

More generally, we now see that the restricted structure on a quantized algebra is exactly analogous to the Dyer-Lashof operation on of a coconnective even-concentrated --algebra. Let’s now try to make this precise in the case of Hochschild cohomology. Recall that if is a smooth -algebra, then the Hochschild cohomology (I would use different notation, but also has a meaning in this world, and Hochschild cohomology is the center) is coconnective, and has (where ). In particular, is the -vector space of derivations .

Given such a derivation , the Leibniz rule implies that is a derivation, and this is the derivation denoted . There is an equation

for the th power of the sum of two derivations and , which looks exactly like the equation for of a sum. (Both are grouped under the name “Jacobson formula”.) We would therefore like the assignment to be observed by in Hochschild cohomology, but this doesn’t quite work: , and sends to . However, if we could look at a “sheared” version of , such that is also an --algebra, and such that , then the Dyer-Lashof operation would operate on by .

This gives us some good impetus to talk about “shearing”, which we also briefly mentioned last time. In characteristic zero, the shearing of a filtered -module is the sheared Rees construction , where is placed in degree by . You can’t write out such an expression in this way for a filtered module over a general -ring, but we can still extract a procedure for doing the analogous construction. Let us focus only on the case of the Whitehead filtration , where we also assume that has an -action.

We shall construct a -module such that is concentrated in even degrees, , and the action of on is given by

where the differential comes from the action of . Moreover, the assignment will be lax symmetric monoidal, so when we plug in , we will get our desired --algebra .

The construction we’re about to describe can be found in this paper, but it’s not phrased in this way there. This “doubling” procedure is a decalage given by the underlying -module of the connective cover . The differentials in the homotopy fixed point spectral sequence for the -action on then describe the action of on the associated graded (of the filtration via the Beilinson connective cover), which gives the claim of the previous paragraph. Importantly, this construction is lax symmetric monoidal; therefore, because is a filtered -ring, we see that if was an --algebra, then is an --algebra.

So far, we have just seen that the assignment of the th power of a derivation to a derivation is a special case of the Dyer-Lashof operation . We still haven’t addressed what a Frobenius-constant structure on a quantized algebra is supposed to be homotopified by under the equation . By the discussion in the previous posts, the homotopical analogue of a quantization of a -algebra is the datum of an -action on . The splitting is then homotopified by the datum of a Frobenius-linear map — but not just any map, because, as we saw, this should have something to do with power operations. We can bake this right into the -action: if we ask that the -action on make it into a cyclotomic spectrum (see Nikolaus-Scholze), then we have an -equivariant “Frobenius” map . This map encodes the datum of the “total power operation” on ; see, for instance, Proposition IV.1.16 in Nikolaus-Scholze. We might therefore expect that, in “characteristic ”, the data of -actions homotopify deformation quantization, and the data of cyclotomic spectra homotopify Frobenius-constant quantizations. It’s a little difficult to make this precise (and I still haven’t been able to do so), because we have to grapple with the (related) issues of working with -rings, and this “shearing” procedure, to really see the power operation and its interaction with the restricted structure/splitting. I’m trying to think about how this cyclotomic spectra perspective on Frobenius-constant quantizations can be used to reprove (or at least, homotopify) some of Bezrukavnikov-Kaledin’s results (like the Azumaya property of -inverted quantizations, for instance).

Obviously, I’ve not given any precise statement in any of the previous posts, but being precise wasn’t the intent of these posts. I just wanted to describe the dictionary between deformation quantization, filtrations, and -actions in characteristic zero, and how utilizing -actions in the world of spectra provides a “derived algebraic geometry”/sphere spectrum lift of deformation quantization. In a certain sense, this derived lift of deformation quantization is more rigid, but I’d argue this is “better” because it takes into account the additional structure present in spectra (like the widespread failure of formality away from characteristic zero). I think it would be very interesting to explore deformation quantization over the sphere spectrum from this perspective.
